content.description: Climb the mossy crack up into a much cleaner, prominent right facing corner.  Follow this up, then escape onto the face to the right.  Climb the face to the pine up top.
content.protection: Looked awesome.  Top roped it, but gear looked solid.
content.location: two or three feet climber's right of "not tell wife, okay?" There is a rather large,flat-topped block on the path; this climb starts directly in front of the block.

content.description: Follow the corner past some bulges.
content.protection: We top roped it, but gear looked great.
content.location: About 65-70 ft right of the left end of the crag, and 15-20 feet to the right of the first climb (Short Sharp Shocked, 5.4) which is a right facing corner with a birch tree in it.  Find a right facing corner with a clean arete. (Photo)

content.description: Climb up the 20' tall, shallow right facing corner to its top.  Climb cracks to the bulge in the face, then jam, foot jam, and high step until you reach the jug over the lip (crux).  Then face climb right after the pine-tree ledge.
content.protection: Pro looked good.  We top roped it.
content.location: About the middle of the cliff, ten or fifteen feet to the left of Monkey. Find a mossy, slabby, right facing corner that ends about 15' up. There is a rather large, flat-topped block on the path; this climb starts about 3 ft left of that block.

content.description: Find the main right facing corner on climber's right end of the cliff.  Climb the corner to the top, gaining it with a slabby crack for about 10' off the ground.  Crux is up high with some strenuous stemming.
content.location: This is the major right facing, clean corner on climbers right end of the cliff, about 3 ft right of “Gifts‘ bolt”.The climb Day Tripper, 5.9 also starts in the same place but moves left after the first few moves of Monkey.

climbs.name: Guides Gift
climbs.fa: Tad Welch, Steve Jones Jim Lawyer Sept 2007

content.description: Climb the corner to anchor shared with Rumble Strips.  Part way up you can even clip one of the two bolts on an “unknown” climb that starts a few feet right of ”Guides”, although rest assured this is a 100% trad climb!
content.protection: Std rack,  plus #3. You could even put in a #4 if you brought it along.
content.location: 8-10 ft right of Rumble Strips, at a big (20 inch diameter) pine tree.

climbs.name: Gifts of Promiscuity
climbs.fa: Ross Manny, Geanette Orton, Nick Orton May 25, 2020

content.description:
This is not only the hardest, but also the best line on this wall. It is varied, mostly sustained, direct, and has aesthetic appeal. This is the hard way out that is alluded to in the Lawyer/Haas description of Day Tripper (5.9). It can also be easily toproped by leading any nearby route and traversing to the anchors, or walking around and doing some 4th class down climbing.

 Mantle onto the small ledges and clip the bolt. Work your way up to the crack (shared with Day Tripper), and continue to the ledge beneath the second roof and a white pine tree. Step left onto the gently overhanging face and work your way up the two parallel cracks (crux). Make a couple of difficult moves straight up to the large ledge and fixed anchors.
content.protection: Single rack to #2 and nuts. Microcams helpful. Fixed anchor.
content.location: 4' left of Monkey, at some small ledges below a shallow right facing corner and the first ceiling of Day Tripper 12' up. About 6-8 ft right of the block on the path and directly below a bolt.

content.description: More sustained and difficult than it looks.Climb the corner until it ends at a triangle shaped roof. Step left and make a difficult move to gain the crack above. Continue up the crack system on the face (crux) to topout at the fixed anchor shared with Gifts of Promiscuity.
content.protection: Standard rack from small cams to #1 Camalot and nuts. Fixed anchor.
content.location: Directly between Sharp Bridge and Gifts of Promiscuity at a right facing corner that begins at ground level. This is about 5 ft right of the rather large, flat-topped rock on the path.

content.description: Looking for dry rock? Come to the OTHER side of the northway, and sample the quick-drying cliffs. Similar to Deadwater, this cliff is in an area typified by quick drying sandy soil, clean rock, and a remote feel, notwithstanding the mellow approach.A couple very clean, aesthetic sections are split up by lichen-coated stripes. Some very unique holds and very grippy, fine-grained rock.The first climb you come to, about 50 ft from where the path hits the crag, is “Short Sharp Stacked” (5.4 in the Lawyer-Hass guidebook) which for some reason nobody’s put into MtnPrject yet. There’s a birch tree in the corner about 30 ft up, although the route goes left of this “feature”.
